subsection_content_1: The FAO concludes that after almost 350,000 wild birds have been tested in Africa, Asia, Europe and the Americas, without finding bird flu, that the spread is mostly contained in domestic poultry. "We know now that we haven't found a [wild bird] species that even suggests that it would be a reservoir for this disease," Newman said.
subsection_content_3: The WHO has released new guidelines for acceptance of human H5N1 cases from national laboratories including the use of RT-PCR tests. Story is posted on the Web site of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy.
subsection_content_2: Russia. At a farm in the Krasnodar Territories 410 birds have died and H5N1 has been identified as the cause, according to a spokesman for Rosselkoznadzor, Russia's animal and plant health watchdog agency. All 22,000 birds at the farm will be destroyed. Bird flu was previously detected in the same region in January. This is the third H5N1 outbreak in poultry in Russia this year.
